title: التَّحْذِيرُ وَالإِغْرَاءُ
description: Learn about التحذير (warning against something) and الإغراء (urging toward something) - special accusative constructions in classical Arabic.

notes.title: What is التحذير (Warning)?
content: التَّحْذِير is a grammatical construction used to warn someone against something harmful or undesirable. The warned-against noun is in the accusative case (مَنْصُوب) because it is the object of a deleted verb (احْذَرْ - beware).
This is a classical Arabic structure found frequently in the Quran, hadith, and poetry. The verb is obligatorily deleted, and the warning is conveyed through the accusative noun alone.

examples.english: Beware of lying (lit: yourself and lying)
The lion! The lion! (warning by repetition)
The road! The road! (watch out for the road)

notes.title: Forms of التحذير
content: التحذير has several forms: 1) Using إِيَّاكَ (yourself) followed by وَ and the warned-against noun, 2) Repeating the noun twice, 3) Using the noun with a conjunction to another noun.

The إِيَّاكَ form is the most emphatic. It literally means 'yourself and [the thing]' - i.e., keep yourself away from it. The pronoun إِيَّا changes based on the addressee: إِيَّاكَ (you masc.), إِيَّاكِ (you fem.), إِيَّاكُمَا, إِيَّاكُمْ, إِيَّاكُنَّ.
keyPoints: إِيَّاكَ وَ + noun: most emphatic form

examples.english: Your head and the ceiling! (watch out)

notes.title: What is الإغراء (Urging)?
content: الإِغْرَاء is the opposite of التحذير - it urges someone toward something good or desirable. The urged-toward noun is also مَنْصُوب because it is the object of a deleted verb (الْزَمْ - adhere to, or اطْلُبْ - seek).
Like التحذير, الإغراء omits the verb and conveys meaning through the accusative noun. It is used to encourage virtuous qualities or beneficial actions.

examples.english: Your brother! Your brother! (take care of him)

notes.title: Grammatical Analysis (الإعراب)
content: In both التحذير and الإغراء, the noun is مَفْعُول بِهِ لِفِعْلٍ مَحْذُوفٍ وُجُوبًا (object of an obligatorily deleted verb). The deleted verb is estimated as احْذَرْ for warning and الْزَمْ for urging.
When إِيَّاكَ is used, it is also مَفْعُول بِهِ for the same deleted verb. The وَ that follows is وَاوُ الْمَعِيَّة (waw of accompaniment) or can be considered عَاطِفَة.

examples.arabic: إِيَّاكَ: مفعول به لفعل محذوف تقديره احْذَرْ
examples.english: إِيَّاكَ: object of deleted verb estimated as 'beware'

examples.arabic: الصَّلَاةَ: مفعول به لفعل محذوف تقديره الْزَمْ
examples.english: الصَّلَاةَ: object of deleted verb estimated as 'adhere to'

notes.title: When Deletion is Obligatory vs. Permissible
content: The verb deletion is وَاجِب (obligatory) when: 1) إِيَّاكَ is used, 2) The noun is repeated, 3) The noun is conjoined with another using وَ. In these cases, you cannot express the verb.
The deletion is جَائِز (permissible) when a single unrepeated noun is used. You can say الأَسَدَ (the lion!) or احْذَرِ الأَسَدَ (beware of the lion).
keyPoints: وَاجِب: with إِيَّاكَ, repetition, or conjunction
إِيَّاكَ والكذبَ: verb must be deleted
الأَسَدَ: verb can be expressed or deleted

examples.english: Beware of the dog (expressing verb permissible)

notes.title: Classical and Quranic Examples
content: These constructions are abundant in classical Arabic. The Prophet ﷺ used التحذير frequently in hadith: إِيَّاكُمْ وَالظَّنَّ (Beware of suspicion). Arabic poetry also uses these forms for rhetorical effect.
In Quran: إِيَّاكَ نَعْبُدُ (You alone we worship) uses إِيَّاكَ for emphasis/restriction, though this is a different grammatical structure (تقديم المفعول للحصر).

examples.arabic: إِيَّاكُمْ وَالظَّنَّ فَإِنَّ الظَّنَّ أَكْذَبُ الْحَدِيثِ
examples.english: Beware of suspicion, for suspicion is the most lying speech (Hadith)
Seriousness! Seriousness! O seeker of knowledge
